vocabURI="http://lod.data-archive.ac.uk/skoshasset/1ce4fadc-424b-4abd-b2a6-4adb7ff4280d">UNDERAGE DRINKING</keyword>         <topcClas>Consumer behaviour - Economics</topcClas>         <topcClas>Drug abuse, alcohol and smoking - Health</topcClas>         <topcClas>Social attitudes and behaviour - Society and culture</topcClas>         <topcClas>Youth - Social stratification and groupings</topcClas>       </subject>       <abstract><p>Abstract copyright UK Data Service and data collection copyright owner.</p>The <i>Smoking, Drinking and Drug Use among Young People</i> survey series began in 1982, under the name <i>Smoking among Secondary Schoolchildren</i>.  The series initially aimed to provide national estimates of the proportion of secondary schoolchildren aged 11-15 who smoked, and to describe their smoking behaviour. Similar surveys were carried out every two years until 1998 to monitor trends in the prevalence of cigarette smoking. The survey then moved to an annual cycle, and questions on alcohol consumption and drug use were included. The name of the series was accordingly changed to <i>Smoking, Drinking and Drug Use among Young Teenagers</i> to reflect this widened focus. In 2000, the series title changed, to <i>Smoking, Drinking and Drug Use among Young People</i>. The survey has been carried out every year in England since 2000 by the National Centre for Social Research (now NatCen Social Research) and the National Foundation for Educational Research. From 2005, the Information Centre for Health and Social Care (from 2013 the Health and Social Care Information Centre) took over from the Department of Health as sponsors.  <br> <br> In alternate survey years, beyond the core questions, the remainder of the questionnaire focuses on either smoking and drinking or on drug taking. The 2001, 2003, 2005, 2007, 2009  and 2011 surveys focused mainly on drugs, and the 2000, 2002, 2004, 2006, 2008, 2010 and 2012 surveys focused mainly on smoking and drinking.  It should be noted that the UK Data Archive holds the survey only from 1988 onwards.<br> <br> In some years, the surveys have been carried out in Scotland and Wales, as well as England, to provide separate national estimates for these countries. In 2002, following a review of Scotland's future information needs in relation to drug misuse among schoolchildren, a separate Scottish series (see under GN 33354) was established by the Scottish Executive.<br> <br> </abstract>       <abstract><B>Main Topics</B>:<br>The 2006 survey focused mainly on smoking and drinking, as set by the focus pattern of the survey series.<br> <br> Topics covered include smoking and smoking behaviour, family attitudes towards smoking, drinking and drinking behaviour, alcohol drunk in last week, methods of obtaining alcohol, 'binge' drinking, drug use, attitudes to smoking, drinking and drug use, and drug education. Classificatory, school and demographic information is also included in the data file. Some administrative variables have been removed in order to ensure respondent confidentiality is maintained (for example date of interview and day of date of birth).<br> <br> Most schools also completed a policy questionnaire, which covered guidelines on adult (staff and visitors) smoking on school premises, disciplinary action for pupils found smoking, drinking or taking drugs on school premises, and policy for dealing with pupils not caught in the act of taking, but clearly under the influence of, drugs or alcohol at school.</abstract>       <sumDscr>         <collDate event="start" date="2006-09-01T00:00:00Z">September 2006</collDate>         <collDate event="end" date="2006-12-01T00:00:00Z">December 2006</collDate>         <nation>England</nation>         <geogUnit>No spatial unit</geogUnit>         <anlyUnit>Individuals</anlyUnit>         <universe>National</universe>         <universe>Secondary school pupils in England, aged 11-15 years, during 2006.</universe>         <dataKind>Numeric data</dataKind>         <dataKind> Individual (micro) level</dataKind>       </sumDscr>     </stdyInfo>     <method>       <dataColl>         <timeMeth>Repeated cross-sectional study</timeMeth>         <sampProc>Multi-stage stratified random sample</sampProc>         <collMode>Face-to-face interview; Self-completion</collMode>         <collMode>The policy questionnaire was delivered via face-to-face interview, but pupils were given a self-completion questionnaire.</collMode>         <sources>           <dataSrc>The NFER database of schools, which contained information supplied by the Department for Education and Skills, was used.</dataSrc>         </sources>         <weight>No weighting used.</weight>         <cleanOps>B</cleanOps>       </dataColl>     </method>     <dataAccs>       <setAvail>         <accsPlac>UK Data Service</accsPlac>       </setAvail>       <useStmt>         <specPerm>Standard conditions of access</specPerm>         <restrctn>The depositor has specified that registration is required and standard conditions of use apply. The depositor may be informed about usage.
